alt_statements.statement: As someone who spends a lot of time outside with my kids and cares about caring for the land the way my Cherokee elders taught me, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of real consequences and real education. We need stricter fines and consistent enforcement, but also well-funded community programs in schools and neighborhoods that teach respect for the earth and provide plenty of trash and recycling bins. I’d love to see local governments partner with tribal communities and churches to organize regular cleanups and cultural events that connect keeping public spaces clean with our shared responsibility to creation.

As someone who values personal responsibility and taking care of the community my kids are growing up in, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and basic civic education. There should be clear fines for those who litter, along with enough trash cans and recycling bins so people have no excuse, but we should also teach children in schools and in church communities that keeping our streets and parks clean is a matter of respect—for each other, for the environment, and for God’s creation.

Working with cement and concrete every day, I see firsthand how much material we use and how important it is not to waste or trash our surroundings, so I think strong anti-littering policies need to mix clear fines with plenty of trash and recycling bins in every public space. We should also invest in community clean-up programs, public art made from reclaimed materials, and environmental education, so people feel pride and responsibility for the spaces they share.

As someone who works in a library and values clean, welcoming community spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of practical measures and education. Cities should provide plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, enforce reasonable fines for littering, and pair that with public campaigns—especially in schools—to teach people why caring for shared spaces matters. I’d also like to see more community clean-up events, where families and kids can take part, because when people feel ownership of their parks and sidewalks, they’re less likely to treat them like a trash can.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of personal responsibility and some practical rules. Cities should put more trash and recycling bins where people actually need them and enforce fines for littering, but we also need steady public reminders—signs, local campaigns, maybe even school programs—so folks think twice before tossing something on the ground. I’m not big on heavy-handed government, but I don’t see a problem with clear penalties when someone’s carelessness makes shared spaces worse for everyone.

Having worked in healthcare, I’ve seen firsthand how a dirty environment can impact both physical and mental well-being, so I believe we need a mix of strict enforcement and practical support to keep public spaces clean. Clear signage, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and meaningful fines for littering would help, but so would community clean-up days that give people a shared sense of responsibility. I also think schools should teach kids early on about caring for the environment—when people feel connected to nature, whether it’s birds in a park or flowers in a garden, they’re less likely to treat it like a dumping ground.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors bird watching, I’m painfully aware of how litter degrades habitats and harms wildlife, so I strongly support a mix of strict, well-enforced anti-littering fines and robust public education campaigns. Cities should invest in plentiful, clearly marked trash and recycling bins, bottle-deposit and take-back programs, and community clean-up efforts that make caring for shared spaces a social norm rather than an afterthought.

Working in a public school and raising young kids, I see every day how a clean environment shapes how we treat each other and our community. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong, consistently enforced fines, plenty of accessible trash and recycling bins, and real education starting in elementary school that connects caring for our shared spaces with caring for each other and the planet. I’d also love to see more community clean-up days and student-led projects, because when people—especially kids—help keep a place clean, they’re a lot less likely to trash it.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how our environment affects people’s well-being, I think we need a mix of practical policies and real consequences to prevent littering. Clear, well-placed trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup crews, and visible signage should be paired with meaningful fines and mandatory community service for repeat offenders. I also think schools and local community groups should teach kids early on about taking responsibility for shared spaces, because that’s what really sticks long term. Public spaces are part of our kids’ future, and we should treat them like that.

Coming from Honduras and now living here without much money or even health insurance, I see how litter mostly piles up in the neighborhoods where people already feel ignored. The best way to prevent littering is to combine strict enforcement and plenty of trash and recycling bins with education and community clean‑up programs, so people actually feel responsible for their own streets. Cities should invest in jobs for local youth to maintain public spaces, instead of just handing out fines, so caring for the environment becomes a shared, paid responsibility, not just a punishment. That’s how we show real respect for each other and for the places we all use.

In my restaurant, if the kitchen is messy, the food will never come out right; our streets are the same. I think we need stricter fines for littering, more trash and recycling bins where people actually walk, and community clean-up days so neighbors and kids learn to “taste” the pride of a clean neighborhood together. As an immigrant small business owner, I also believe the city should work with local shops and churches to educate people in different languages about keeping public spaces clean, because this is our shared home now.

I think there should be more trash and recycling bins in parks and on streets so people don’t have an excuse to throw garbage on the ground. Schools and churches could teach kids and families why litter hurts animals and nature, and there should be clear signs and maybe small fines so people take it seriously. If we all cleaned up after ourselves, it would make playing outside and exploring way nicer for everyone.

As someone who spends a lot of time enjoying parks, downtown districts, and cultural venues, I think preventing littering has to be a mix of smart design and shared responsibility. Cities should invest in abundant, well-placed trash and recycling bins, enforce fines for littering, and run sustained public campaigns—especially in schools—about environmental stewardship. I’m willing to pay a bit more in local taxes to support cleaner streets and better sanitation services, because a well-kept public space is a basic civic good, not a luxury.

As someone who spends a lot of time out in the community and cares deeply about shared spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong enforcement and smart design: plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and real fines that are actually enforced. We also need public education campaigns, especially in schools and community centers, that treat keeping our streets clean as a civic duty, not an afterthought. And frankly, I’d like to see businesses held accountable too—if they profit from all the packaging, they should help pay for cleanup and prevention programs.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime organizing in the community, I’ve seen that the best way to prevent littering is to make it easy for people to do the right thing: plenty of trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup crews, and well-maintained public spaces that people feel proud of. But we also need education that starts in schools and community centers, along with modest fines that are fairly enforced, so the message is clear that keeping our neighborhoods clean is a shared responsibility. I’d especially support programs that pay local residents—especially youth and seniors—to do community cleanups, turning care for our common spaces into both a civic and economic opportunity.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and walking around my neighborhood, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public policies and personal responsibility. We need more trash and recycling bins in busy areas, consistent fines for littering that are actually enforced, and community education that starts in schools and churches to build respect for shared spaces. I’d also like to see local governments and businesses partner on clean-up days and incentive programs, because when people feel ownership of their parks and streets, they’re less likely to toss garbage on the ground.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins everywhere, and they should have big, colorful signs so people can see them easily. At school and in parks, teachers and grown-ups could teach kids and families why throwing trash on the ground hurts animals and makes our world ugly, maybe with posters and art projects. People who litter on purpose should have to help clean up so they learn how much work it takes to fix the mess. When places are clean and pretty, like in the pictures I like to draw, it makes me feel safer and happier.

If people can’t be bothered to throw their trash in a bin, there ought to be real consequences—hefty fines and actually enforcing them, not just signs. I’d also like to see more trash and recycling cans in parks and along roads, and have schools and churches teach kids early that you respect the land God gave us and the community you live in. Personal responsibility and pride in your town will always do more than another government program.

I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and teaching people to respect our community and God’s creation. There should be real fines and consequences for littering, plus more trash and recycling bins in parks and streets so there’s no excuse. Schools and churches can help by organizing clean-up days and talking about personal responsibility and taking pride in where we live. When families and neighbors actually care about their town, they’re a lot less likely to trash it.

As someone who takes pride in keeping my home and garden neat, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and firm, consistently enforced penalties. Well-placed trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and community clean-up efforts through churches and civic groups can help build a culture where leaving a mess is socially unacceptable. At the same time, there should be meaningful fines for those who litter, with no exceptions, because respect for shared spaces is part of respecting your neighbors and your country.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and walking lots and car lots, I notice how much trash ends up on the ground, and it really bothers me. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong enforcement—clear fines that are actually applied—and making it easy to do the right thing by putting out more trash and recycling bins and keeping them well maintained. We should also invest in community clean-up programs and education, especially in neighborhoods that have been overlooked, so people feel a sense of pride and ownership in their public spaces. When folks see their community cared for, they’re less likely to treat it like a dumping ground.

I don’t like it when people leave trash on the ground because it makes parks and streets look yucky and ruins places where I like to play. I think there should be more trash cans and big signs reminding people to throw their trash away, and grown‑ups should teach kids at school and church that God wants us to take care of the world he made.

If we want people to stop littering, we’ve got to make it both easier to do the right thing and harder to get away with trashing the place. That means more trash and recycling bins where people actually hang out, real fines that are actually enforced, and making companies responsible for all the packaging they flood the streets with. I work in construction and see how fast a site or neighborhood can get wrecked by garbage, so I think cities should require better cleanup plans and community service for people who litter so they see firsthand the mess everyone else has to live with.

I don’t like when people throw trash on the ground because it makes parks and playgrounds look yucky and I can’t play there as much. There should be lots of trash cans and big, colorful signs with heroes that say “Put trash here!” so it’s easy to know what to do. Grown-ups should also remind kids and other grown-ups to pick up their trash, like a superhero team keeping the city clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors with my family, I think strong anti-littering policies really matter—not just fines, but making it easy for people to do the right thing. That means more trash and recycling bins in parks, on sidewalks, and at bus stops, plus clear signage and public campaigns that teach kids early on to respect shared spaces. I’d also support community clean‑up programs and holding businesses accountable for excess packaging and waste, since big companies contribute a lot to what ends up on our streets.

I think if we want people to stop littering, we have to make it both easy and expected to do the right thing. That means plenty of trash and recycling bins, regular street cleaning, and real fines that are actually enforced. I’d also love to see more public art and beautification projects—when a space is cared for and beautiful, folks are less likely to trash it. Cities should put money into community clean‑up days and education in schools too, so respect for shared spaces becomes a habit, not an afterthought.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside at concerts, festivals, and shopping areas, I really notice how trash can ruin a space that’s supposed to feel fun and welcoming. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and real convenience: more trash and recycling bins, clear signs, and fines that are actually enforced when people litter. Cities should also pay people—especially young people—to help with cleanups and community education so it feels like we all have a stake in keeping our neighborhoods clean. Public spaces should feel safe and cared for, especially in Black communities that are too often ignored when it comes to basic cleanliness and services.

At my age, I’ve watched parks and sidewalks slowly fill with trash, and it breaks my heart because public spaces are one of the few places everyone can share equally. I believe the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public education, especially with children, plenty of conveniently placed trash and recycling bins, and meaningful fines that are actually enforced. We should also invest in community cleanup programs and volunteer days, because when people feel ownership and pride in their neighborhoods, they’re far less likely to throw garbage on the ground.

As someone who teaches national security and understands the importance of shared responsibility, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of firm enforcement and strong community norms. Clear penalties and consistent enforcement send the message that public spaces are not “no man’s land,” while well-placed trash and recycling bins, public education in schools and churches, and local volunteer clean-up efforts teach our kids that caring for our surroundings is a matter of personal character and civic duty.

I think the best way to stop littering is to make it easy not to litter, like having more trash and recycling cans in parks, bus stops, and by schools, and emptying them often so they don’t overflow. We should also have gentle but real fines for people who keep littering, and teach kids from a young age—especially in middle school—why trash hurts our neighborhoods, animals, and places where we play sports. I’d love to see more community clean‑up days where families and kids can help out together, because when you help clean a place, you respect it more and don’t want to mess it up.

As someone who spends a lot of time in a community garden and cares deeply about the environment, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of education, accessible infrastructure, and real accountability. Clear signage, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and regular community clean-up events can help people see public spaces as shared, living places rather than dumping grounds. At the same time, there should be meaningful fines for chronic littering and strong support for school-based programs that teach kids early on to respect the land and the people who share it.

Working in healthcare, I see every day how our environment directly affects public health, so preventing littering isn’t just about aesthetics, it’s a basic community wellness issue. I’d also like to see local governments partner with businesses and community groups on regular clean-up days and “adopt-a-spot” initiatives, so people feel real ownership of shared spaces. When we make it easy to do the right thing and reinforce that our parks, sidewalks, and beaches are a shared trust, folks are far less likely to treat them like a dumping ground.

Public spaces are everyone’s responsibility, and I think the most effective way to prevent littering is to have clear rules that are actually enforced, with real fines for people who trash shared areas. At the same time, local governments should make it easy to do the right thing by providing plenty of trash and recycling bins, especially in parks and outdoor recreation spots. I don’t want more feel-good campaigns or bureaucracy—I want straightforward, practical measures that keep our towns and natural areas clean for our families.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of personal responsibility and some common-sense local policies. Clear signage, enough trash and recycling bins, and fines that are actually enforced send the message that our shared spaces matter, but at the end of the day folks need to take pride in their community and clean up after themselves. I’d also support community clean-up days through churches, scout troops, and local groups, because when people have some skin in the game, they’re a lot less likely to treat parks and streets like a dumping ground.

As someone who spends a lot of time volunteering in my community and tending gardens, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of practical policy and education. Cities should provide plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, enforce reasonable fines for littering, and invest in public-awareness campaigns that highlight our shared responsibility to keep neighborhoods clean. I’d also like to see more school and community programs—like neighborhood clean-up days—that make caring for public spaces a point of local pride rather than just a rule to follow. When people feel connected to their surroundings, they’re far less likely to treat them like a dumping ground.

As someone who believes strongly in the interconnectedness of physical, mental, and community health, I see littering as not just an eyesore, but a public health and community-respect issue. I’d also support community-based cleanup programs and incentives, because when people are actively involved in caring for their environment, they’re much less likely to trash it in the first place.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and really values clean, active public spaces for yoga and dancing, I think we need a mix of strong enforcement and smart design to prevent littering. When neighbors are involved in keeping parks and sidewalks clean, it builds shared responsibility and respects the land and our Indigenous belief that nature is sacred.

Para mí, evitar la basura en los espacios públicos empieza por educar con respeto, desde las escuelas hasta las iglesias y las familias, para que la gente entienda que tirar basura daña la creación de Dios y nuestra salud. También es importante que el gobierno ponga botes de basura y reciclaje suficientes, cobre multas justas a quien contamine, y ofrezca programas comunitarios donde vecinos, incluyendo inmigrantes como yo, podamos participar en jornadas de limpieza y cuidado del medio ambiente.

As a retired teacher and someone who takes great comfort in tending my garden, I believe strong anti-littering policies should combine clear enforcement with thoughtful education. Public campaigns that appeal to our sense of responsibility to neighbors and the next generation can be very effective. As someone who spent a career in community development and environmental conservation, I’ve seen that the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of smart policy and local pride: strong enforcement of fines, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and public education that starts young and is rooted in respect for our shared spaces. I’d also like to see deposit-return systems expanded and funded community clean-up initiatives, because when neighbors roll up their sleeves together, people are a lot less likely to trash a park or sidewalk they feel they truly own.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside gardening and walking around my neighborhood, it really bothers me to see trash everywhere, especially when it’s so easy to carry a reusable bottle or hold onto your waste until you find a bin. I think the most effective policies combine plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling cans with real enforcement—like fines that are actually issued—plus public education campaigns that make not littering feel like a basic community norm. I’d also support programs that involve local businesses and schools in cleanup days and anti-litter messaging, so people feel more personally responsible for keeping shared spaces clean.

In our culture we are taught from young to respect shared spaces and not bring shame to our family or community, so I believe strong social expectations and public education are just as important as fines for littering. The government should put more trash and recycling bins in convenient places, post clear signs in multiple languages, and enforce penalties consistently so people understand there are real consequences. Neighborhood groups and businesses can also work together to organize regular clean-ups, which build community responsibility and make it harder for anyone to treat public spaces carelessly. When everyone feels a duty to keep the environment clean, people will think twice before throwing garbage on the ground.

As someone who cares a lot about my neighborhood and spends time gardening and walking outside, I think the best way to prevent littering is to make it easy for people to do the right thing—more trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup days, and clear signs in both English and Spanish. We also need schools and community groups to teach respect for shared spaces, and local governments should actually enforce fines when people litter, so it’s not just a suggestion but a real expectation.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling bins where people actually hang out, especially in parks, bus stops, and near schools, and make sure they’re emptied often. There should be real fines for littering, but also community clean‑up days so people feel like these spaces belong to us and we want to keep them clean. Schools could teach more about how trash hurts our neighborhoods and the environment, and cities should use art—like murals and painted trash cans—to remind people not to just throw stuff on the ground.

As someone who served this country, I see littering as a sign of disrespect—not just for the land we share, but for the people who fought to protect it. As someone who’s spent a lifetime teaching kids to take responsibility for their actions, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public education, visible trash and recycling bins, and real consequences for folks who still choose to litter. We ought to invest in community clean-up programs, especially in Black and low-income neighborhoods that often get neglected, and pair that with clear fines for repeat offenders so the message sticks. Public campaigns that appeal to community pride—“don’t trash our Texas”–style messaging—can go a long way, especially when people see their neighbors and local leaders walking the walk.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling cans everywhere and make them easy to find, because sometimes people are just lazy. If there were small rewards or contests for neighborhoods that stay the cleanest, I think more people would actually care.

As a public school teacher, I see every day how much behavior is shaped by what we teach, model, and reinforce, so I think the best anti-litter policies combine education with clear rules and real consequences. Cities should invest in abundant, well-marked trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup crews, and public campaigns—especially in schools—to build a culture of shared responsibility. At the same time, meaningful fines and community-service requirements for littering can reinforce that our public spaces are a common good, not someone else’s problem to clean up.

As someone who grew up in Spain and loves spending time outside socializing and enjoying music, I hate seeing public spaces trashed with litter. For me, protecting public spaces is about respecting the community and the environment, not just following rules.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling bins everywhere and make sure they’re easy to find and use. There should still be fines for people who keep littering on purpose, but it would help more if we made it normal and expected for everyone to clean up after themselves.

I hate seeing trash all over the park and skate spots, because it makes them gross and people start treating them worse. As someone who spends a lot of time walking across campus and reading in public spaces, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of smart design and shared responsibility: plentiful, clearly labeled trash and recycling bins, regular maintenance, and visible norms that make clean spaces feel like the standard, not the exception. Fines and enforcement have their place, but I’d rather see schools and cities invest in education campaigns, student-led initiatives, and community clean-ups that help people feel collectively responsible for the spaces we use together.

As a young mom who spends a lot of time in parks and public spaces with my kids, I really want our community to stay clean and safe so they can play without trash everywhere. As someone who runs an ad agency and spends a lot of time at parks and events with my kids, I think we need a mix of smart design, strong enforcement, and strong messaging to prevent littering. As someone who spends a lot of time in my garden and cares deeply about the environment, it breaks my heart to see trash in our parks and streets. As someone who takes pride in keeping my home and garden tidy, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a combination of personal responsibility and real consequences. As someone who spends his days keeping buildings clean, I know firsthand that the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and clear, enforced rules. I also believe families, schools, and churches should teach respect for shared spaces, so people learn early on that keeping our streets and parks clean is everyone’s duty.

I can’t stand seeing trash all over our parks and parking lots, and I think people need to take more personal responsibility instead of expecting the government to clean up after them. As a progressive and a dad raising young kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and everyday accountability. Living in dense cities, I’ve seen how much a clean street changes how people treat each other and the space itself. As someone who spends a lot of time outside with kids, I really believe strong anti-littering policies should combine clear rules and fines with plenty of trash and recycling bins, plus regular community clean-up days. As someone who teaches at a university and cares deeply about how diverse communities share public spaces, I think the best policies to prevent littering combine education, convenience, and consistent enforcement. As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors gardening and going to community wellness events, I find litter really undermines both our health and our shared public spaces. As a preschool teacher and a mom, I see every day how much kids learn from what we model, so strong anti-littering policies should start with education and visible community standards—like plenty of trash and recycling bins, clear signs, and school-based programs that make caring for our environment feel normal and proud. As someone who spends a lot of time skating around town and hanging out in parks, I see how trash piles up and makes public spaces feel uncared for, especially in neighborhoods like mine. As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and believes in personal responsibility, I think the best way to prevent littering is to strictly enforce fines and make people face real consequences for trashing shared spaces. As a mental health counselor and someone who spends a lot of time in nature, I see littering not just as an environmental problem but as a sign of how disconnected people can feel from their communities and surroundings. As someone who spends a lot of time in parks, gardens, and community spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, accessible infrastructure, and education. As someone who came from Nigeria and now works with people all day, I know that when a space looks cared for and reflects the community—like when we incorporate local and African-inspired art—people treat it with more respect and are less likely to litter. As someone who cares about keeping our communities clean and values personal responsibility, I think the best way to prevent littering is to enforce existing laws with real fines and consequences, not just put up “Please Don’t Litter” signs. As someone who works in retail and sees firsthand how people treat shared spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and practical measures. I’d also support community clean-up days, where families and neighbors come together to take pride in keeping our town clean.

As a conservative and a lawyer, I see littering primarily as a breakdown of individual responsibility and respect for shared property. When I go to the park with my family, it makes me sad to see trash on the grass where I want to play with my toy cars. I think there should be lots of trash cans with big, easy pictures so kids and grown-ups know where to put things, and teachers at church and school should remind us that God wants us to take care of His world. If people still throw trash on the ground, I think they should have to help clean the park so they learn not to do it again.

I think the best way to stop littering is to teach kids and grown‑ups why keeping places clean is important, starting in school and at home. There should be more trash and recycling cans around, and people who litter on purpose should have to help clean up as a consequence so they learn it’s not fair to everyone else. Churches and community groups could also have regular clean-up days, so we all share the job of taking care of God’s creation.

As someone who spends a lot of time gardening, walking in my neighborhood, and volunteering in the community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules and strong local involvement. We should have visible trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and school and community programs that teach respect for shared spaces. I also believe in organizing volunteer clean-up events and public campaigns that appeal to people’s sense of responsibility and care for the environment, rather than just scolding them. When people feel ownership of their parks and sidewalks, they’re much less likely to toss trash on the ground.

As someone who cares about keeping our community clean and safe, I think we need a mix of personal responsibility and firm consequences to prevent littering. Clear signage, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and community clean‑up days can encourage people to take pride in shared spaces, but there should also be meaningful fines and enforcement for those who don’t respect the rules. Teaching kids early—at home, in church, and in school—that caring for God’s creation and our neighborhoods is part of good character will make a bigger difference than any government program alone.

As someone who cleans homes and buildings for a living, it really bothers me to see trash thrown all over our streets and parks. I think we need stricter fines for littering, more trash cans in public places, and clear signs so people know the rules. Parents and churches should also teach children to respect God’s creation and keep our communities clean. Personal responsibility and good example go a long way, but there must also be consequences for those who don’t care.

As someone who spends a lot of time moving between clinics and community spaces, I see litter as both a public health issue and a reflection of whether we take our shared responsibilities seriously. The most effective approach blends clear, consistently enforced rules (with fines that actually get collected) and practical infrastructure—plenty of bins, good lighting, and regular cleanup—alongside sustained public education that appeals to our sense of stewardship, not just fear of punishment. I’d also like to see cities partner with nonprofits and neighborhood groups to organize cleanups and give residents a real stake in keeping spaces beautiful and safe.

Where I’m from, folks say “you don’t trash what you love,” and I think that ought to guide our litter policies. The best approach is a mix of strong, consistently enforced fines for littering, plenty of well-placed recycling and trash bins, and bottle-deposit or “pay-as-you-throw” systems that make waste reduction the easy, obvious choice. I’d also love to see cities partner with local businesses and schools on environmental education and neighborhood cleanups, so people feel real pride and ownership over their public spaces.

As someone who runs a travel accommodation business and has seen how beautiful destinations can be spoiled by trash, I think strong anti-littering policies need to combine clear fines with plenty of well-placed bins and regular public education campaigns. We should treat clean public spaces as a shared cultural value—like many European cities do—so that people feel a social responsibility, not just a legal obligation, to dispose of waste properly. I’d also support community cleanup events and incentives for businesses to reduce single-use packaging, because when locals and visitors work together, è tutta un’altra cosa—it changes the whole atmosphere of a place.

At my age, having watched this country change over many decades, I’m convinced the best way to prevent littering is to reinforce personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces, not just pass new regulations. Clear, consistently enforced fines, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and community service requirements for offenders would help, but we also need schools, churches, and local civic groups to teach younger generations that caring for our streets and parks is simply part of good citizenship and moral duty.

As someone who has spent a lifetime teaching young people and now takes quiet walks through my community, I believe the most effective way to prevent littering is a combination of education, accessible infrastructure, and fair enforcement. We should invest in early education about care for creation and shared spaces, ensure there are plenty of bins and recycling options, and apply reasonable fines when people disregard the common good. To me, keeping our parks and streets clean is both a matter of social justice and respect for one another, especially for those who rely most on public spaces.

As someone who loves being outdoors and cares a lot about health and community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong local policies and smart design. We should have more trash and recycling bins that are clearly marked and easy to find, enforce fines for littering consistently, and invest in public education campaigns—especially ones that speak to kids and families—about how trash affects our water, parks, and neighborhoods. I’d also love to see cities partner with local businesses and community groups to sponsor clean-up days and create a stronger sense of shared responsibility for public spaces.

As someone who walks between clients’ homes every day and volunteers at community events, I see how much litter can change the feel and safety of a neighborhood. The best way to prevent it is a mix of stronger enforcement with real fines, plenty of trash and recycling bins that are actually maintained, and community education that treats clean streets as a shared responsibility—especially involving churches, schools, and neighborhood groups. I’d also like to see companies held accountable for excessive packaging and required to help fund cleanup and waste reduction, not just leave it to low-wage workers and volunteers to pick up the mess.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see our towns change, I believe the best way to prevent littering is to combine firm enforcement with personal responsibility. We should have clear fines that are actually enforced, plenty of trash and recycling bins in public areas, and public campaigns—especially through churches, schools, and local community groups—that teach people to respect shared spaces as part of good citizenship and stewardship of God’s creation.

Working in restaurants and bars, I see firsthand how much trash people generate without thinking, so I really believe in a mix of strict rules and making it easy to do the right thing. Cities should invest in plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup crews, and public education, but also actually enforce fines for littering so it’s not just a suggestion. I’d also support policies that push businesses—especially takeout and fast-food places—to use less single-use packaging and help fund cleanup efforts. Keeping public spaces clean is a basic respect issue for the community, and government should take the lead instead of leaving it all to volunteers.

As someone who works in construction and cares about the way our built environment looks and functions, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of common-sense policy and shared responsibility. We need plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, consistent fines that are actually enforced, and well-funded city crews, but we also need public education—especially in schools—so people see clean streets and parks as something we all own together. I’d support local ordinances that hold businesses and event organizers partly accountable for trash around their properties, paired with community clean-up days that make it easy and normal for neighbors to pitch in. Keeping our public spaces clean isn’t just about appearances—it shows respect for each other and for the neighborhoods we’ve built.

I was raised to believe you clean up after yourself and respect shared spaces, and I still feel that way when I see trash along our streets and parks. I think we need a mix of stricter enforcement with real fines, plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, and regular cleanup days that encourage neighbors to pitch in together. Schools should also teach children early on about personal responsibility and pride in their community, so good habits stick for life.

I think there should be more trash and recycling cans everywhere, especially near playgrounds, so it’s easy for people to throw things away instead of dropping them on the ground. Grown‑ups should teach kids at home and at school that God wants us to take care of the world He made, so littering is wrong and makes parks and sidewalks look yucky.

As someone who cares a lot about my neighborhood and spends time volunteering, I think the best way to stop littering is a mix of real consequences and real community investment. We should have strict fines and enough trash and recycling bins everywhere, but also fund local clean-up programs, school education, and youth jobs that teach pride in our public spaces. I’d also like to see big companies held accountable for excess packaging and required to help pay for cleanup, not just leave it on working-class communities like mine to deal with.

I’ve spent years making sure things run smoothly and safely at work, and I see our public spaces the same way: if we want clean parks, sidewalks, and bus stops, we need clear rules, consistent enforcement, and basic personal responsibility. The best policies combine visible trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and regular community clean‑up events so people feel some ownership of their neighborhoods.

As a mom raising young kids in a busy city and someone who cares a lot about health, I see littering as both a public health problem and a values problem. We need a mix of strong policies—like consistent fines, plenty of accessible trash and recycling bins, and well-maintained public spaces—alongside community education that teaches respect for shared environments. I’d also support programs that involve schools, churches, and local businesses in cleanup efforts, because when people feel ownership over their parks and sidewalks, they’re much less likely to trash them.

At my age, having watched this country change over nearly a century, I’m convinced that the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and steady public education. We ought to impose meaningful fines and make sure they’re actually enforced, but pair that with well-designed public campaigns and plenty of visible trash and recycling receptacles so people have no excuse. I also think schools, libraries, and community centers should teach the historical and environmental costs of our throwaway culture, so people understand that littering isn’t just untidy—it’s a sign of civic neglect. As a liberal, I see this as a basic matter of shared responsibility and respect for the common good.

As a mom of little kids who spends a lot of time in parks and playgrounds, it really bothers me to see litter where families are trying to relax and play. I think the most effective approach combines plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, consistent fines that are actually enforced, and visible community involvement—like volunteer cleanups and school programs that teach kids respect for shared spaces. As someone who works with families, I see how much behavior is shaped by what’s “normal,” so cities should focus on making clean, well‑maintained public spaces the norm and celebrating people who help keep them that way.

I think we need stricter fines and real enforcement for littering, because folks don’t seem to take it seriously unless it hits their wallet. But it’s not just about punishment—teaching kids in school and at church about respecting God’s creation and keeping our neighborhoods clean is just as important. If we had more trash cans in busy areas and did regular community clean‑ups, families like mine would feel prouder and safer letting our kids play outside.

I don’t like seeing trash on the ground because it makes parks and sidewalks ugly and can hurt animals that might eat it, and in my religion we’re taught that keeping the earth clean is important. I think there should be more trash and recycling bins everywhere, and schools should teach kids fun lessons and games about not littering and using things again, like art with bottles and boxes. If people still throw trash on the ground on purpose, there should be small fines or they should have to help clean up so they learn to take care of our community.

Working most of my life around power lines and public rights-of-way, I’ve seen firsthand how litter piles up and creates safety hazards as well as eyesores. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement with real fines, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and community clean-up programs that get people invested in keeping their neighborhoods clean. I’m a believer in personal responsibility, but I also think cities and utilities should lead by example, maintaining clean areas around their infrastructure and educating folks—especially kids—about how litter harms local wildlife and the environment.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and enjoys watching birds, I think strong, practical anti-littering policies are essential to protecting our shared spaces. The most effective approach is a mix of clear rules and visible enforcement, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and community education that appeals to basic responsibility rather than politics. Fines for littering should be meaningful enough to matter, but we should also encourage volunteer clean-up days and partnerships with local organizations so people feel personally invested in keeping parks, sidewalks, and trails clean.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors, I’d like to see stronger, common-sense policies to keep our public spaces clean—things like clearly marked trash and recycling bins, regular cleanup programs, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders. But we also need education, especially in schools and community groups, that teaches people to take pride in shared spaces and respect the work it takes to maintain them. Public campaigns and volunteer cleanup days can build that sense of responsibility, so it’s not just about punishment but about community stewardship.
